title: What would happen if suddenly all mosquitoes die? - Quora

response.answer_text: The effects are uncertain. Most of the effects would be fairly subtle in the short term, since mosquitoes aren’t a sole food source for most things that eat them. But there would be impacts, since they are a very easy insect to hunt, as flying insects go (the larva are also hilariously inept). If a species is force to transition from a food source that is very easy to hunt to one that is relatively difficult, the energy loss makes a great difference in how large a population of prey is necessary for a given predation level. One would expect to see the numbers of insect predators in most affected ecosystems drop fairly significantly. Removing an easy prey insect makes the learning curve for young predators much sharper, amplifying the effect. Overall, ecosystems would stabilize by having higher populations of similar insects which turned mucky water (and bits of high-quality protein snagged somewhere) into meals for larger animals. Which insect species would dominate would depend on the specific environment…whatever it was, it would surely be considered a pest in its own right. Populations of insect predators wouldn’t recover to previous levels, unless the replacement insect was similarly easy to hunt. The higher energy cost of hunting something that is better at evading predation can’t be overcome except by having a more favorable ratio of available prey. There would probably be local ecosystems where these small changes would spiral out of control and lead to an ecological collapse. Such a response may even be widespread, it’s not easy to tell for sure. Nor is the picture as simple as painted here. The microbes that take advantage of standing water can have all kinds of impacts, such as on soil fertility. It’s really impossible to even guess what might happen at that largely invisible level. As great a nuisance as mosquitoes can be as disease vectors (and as a direct pest themselves), it’s probably easier to deal with them than what might replace them. And where nothing manages to replace them, the consequences could be dire.

First of all it is impossible. Even if that happens it will happen after the extinction of human. Surprised? Yes, mosquitoes are more tolerant than human and more frequently undergo gene modifications to adapt to the external change. Mosquitoes don't have too many fans. Their bites are itchy, they spread disease, and their numbers swell rapidly. Lets assume they vanished. What will happen? It will be a great LOSS. Yes, you heard it right. Only about a hundred - less than a hundred species transmit those horrible diseases that you've referred to out of thousands of species that live on every continent except Antarctica. you know, it's only the females that take a blood meal from their hosts (she need blood as a protein source for egg development) and often those hosts have nothing to do with humans. So there are mosquitoes that feed on snakes, frogs, birds. Only less than a hundred are a problem for humans. The immature stage(wrigglers or larva) of mosquitoes live in water and can be fed upon by fish and other aquatic predatory insects. Adult Mosquitoes are food for predatory terrestrial insects and birds. Mosquitoes themselves are good pollinators since the males visit flowers to feed on nectar. Certainly mosquitoes are pollinating quite many species. Mosquitoes are the main food item of some species of bat which are also responsible for pollination services. Lastly i will say many people have made careers out them which is their biggest contribution.

There are about 3,500 species of mosquitoes out of which around 200 mosquitoes causes harm to human beings( ONLY FEMALE MOSQUITOES BITE HUMANS). Although it is considered as deadliest disease causing agent, it also has positive role in the environment to certain extent. Let us see its positive role in the environment.. Mosquito larvae for their survival feed on certain algae present in the water and convert them into tissues of their own body. When fishes feed on larvae, its become nutritious packed food for the them playing a role in aquatic food chain.Mosquitoes serve as nutritious food for birds, bats and spiders. Thus it indirectly play a role in increased species diversity which is very vital for maintaining a sustainable ecosystem.Medical Discoveries.When we are bitten by a mosquito, we often do not feel the bite because the mosquito anesthetizes us with its mouth(saliva). Some of these anesthetic properties of mosquito saliva have been studied and incorporated in synthetic forms into local and topical anesthetics people to numb a patient undergoing medical treatment.Only the females of some mosquito species need blood to get the proteins necessary to lay eggs. For the most part, male and female adult mosquitoes depend on nectar for energy. So when collecting nectars, the pollen get attached to its body and transfered to other plants helping in pollination. Thus here it acts as a POLLINATOR. Ex: Arctic bog orchids. So mosquitoes do serve some important function in our environment without which would affect our ecosystem. What would be possible ecosystem impact if mosquitoes suddenly vanishes? According to some ecologists, the loss of mosquitoes would harm most ecosystems. Others believe that other organisms would step in and assume mosquitos’ role as food sources and pollinators. VANISHING (TO BE PRECISE ‘ERADICATION’) OF MOSQUITO IS ALMOST IMPOSSIBLE, UNLESS DESTROYING THE WORLD. The good part of their vanishing.. So many diseases would disappear, so many people would get a good night’s sleep without inhaling chemicals, and so much money that is now being spent on mosquito coils, bednets and medicines would be saved, so many hospital beds would be freed up. EVERY COIN MUST HAVE TWO SIDES. ALL IS GOOD. IMAGE SOURCE: GOOGLE THANKS

Several species of organisms would become extinct in a very short time and it’s possible we could have a wholesale crash of many species if not an entire ecosystem. Those swallows that we see in the late evening darting this way and that around the water’s edge? They’re catching mosquitoes. The bats that take their place just as darkness falls? They eat lots of mosquitoes too. The frogs you hear singing on early summer nights. Yep, mosquitoes are part of their diet as well. Fewer frogs? Well, herons eat frogs. So do egrets and other wading birds. Big fish will eat frogs and they really like tadpoles too. What eats the big fish? Well, people for one. So do all kinds of birds, otters, mink and so on. In short, everything in nature is interconnected. You can’t kill of an entire species and not have some repercussions. Kill a few individuals - no problem. Even kill thousands of individuals with some species and it won’t be noticed. But if you kill off all of them, then the results are unforeseen - but there will. be. downsides. That’s a guarantee. You can probably see it best with the relationship between rabbits and the predators that catch them, especially lynx. The cat’s and rabbit’s populations go up and down in synch with each other. More rabbits, more lynx. Fewer rabbits, fewer lynx. (Also wolves, foxes, hawks and other animals that eat them.) If all the rabbits disappeared, the lynx might disappear too. But if all the lynx were killed off, then rabbits might overpopulate and eat all the new shoots of plants. There’s be more wolves, more foxes, who knows? Mosquitoes are a pain. I hate them. But I wouldn’t want to see them all disappear. I like the swallows, the otters, the herons, and all the other things whose existence depends on whole or on part on them.

It would probably have great repercussions on amphibians, birds and fishs as they’re a crucial step in a very complex who eats who system. Most likely a few very specialized species would die out at first, followed by species who rely on those as their main staple or who rely for more complex reasons (migration patterns or emergence/birthgiving dynamics over years and decades) in some years most likely mosquitos would be more bountyful, in those years other species that only ever emerge every 3, 7, x years or when other conditions are right (that lead to bountyful mosquito years for example) Mosquitoes Role in the Ecosystem The exact effects are hard to envision, sometimes removing or introducing a species to an ecosystem can lead to a complete change/shift of that ecosystem. As was the case with the removal of buffalos (negative impact) or the introduction of wolves into certain areas(positive impact. Both cases completely transformed vast areas of ecosystem into another order/kind of ecosystem. Wolf Reintroduction Changes Ecosystem  Animal impact: how trampling and disturbance benefit grassland ecosystems Elephants, the ecosystem’s engineers, gardeners and architects Birds of prey spread bush fires deliberately To cut it short, our ecosystem would probably change drastically and not for the better Why Eradicating Earth’s Mosquitoes To Fight Disease Is Probably a Bad Idea http://pages.uoregon.edu/mosquito/articles/WEB83biomass.pdf mosquitos are ~50 millon kilograms of potential food source removed from the food chain

Apart from all these Biological perspective , I would like to mention something, All those mosquito repellent companies will be finished.We are relieved from seeing the boring advertisements of mosquito repellents.Mosquito nets on windows, beds, doors become useless and would be used as fish nets.We can have plenty of dirty water all around without fearing mosquito larvae.After the extinction we can see many people cry for mosquitoes, although they were toppers in killing them when they were surplus.Several pathogens will commit suicide.No one in near future will get a hand on the mosquito in amber.

Mosquitoes don't have too many fans. Their bites are itchy, they spread disease, and their numbers swell rapidly. But just what would happen if we all woke up tomorrow in a world that was completely empty of mosquitoes? I googled it out and I found this. If mosquitoes went extinct: Mosquito larvae are very important in aquatic ecology. Many other insects and small fish feed on them and the loss of that food source would cause their numbers to decline as well. Anything that feeds on them, such as game fish, raptorial birds, etc. would in turn suffer too. Mosquitoes can be wiped out but the ecological damage that would be necessary (draining swamps/wetlands, applying pesticides over wide areas), along with strict regulatory enforcement, would make eradication not worth it unless there was a very serious public health emergency. Thanks.

Whereas over a million people die each years from mosquito related diseases, they, like any living creature are an important part of the food chain. Many animals use them as a food source, in all stages of the mosquito’s life cycle. Many small fish eat the larvae as a primary food source, as do numerous insects. Some birds, bats, dragonflies and spiders eat substantial amts. of adult mosquitos. Life is a delicate balance. Remove one component and others suffer. Even something as lowly as a mosquito. This is all the result of eons of evolution. Look how human activities have affected other lifeforms. We kill off the wolf and cougar populations and deer become a nuisance as there are not enough natural predators to keep their numbers in check. We introduce rabbits to Australia and they eat everything in sight leaving little for the indigenous species to survive on. We clear forests for either wood or to make room for growing crops disrupting entire ecosystems. The list goes on and on. Frankly, I think the animal kingdom can’t wait for us to kill ourselves out so that things can go back to “normal”. So, to answer the question, for any existing species to go extinct, even mosquitos would be an eventual disaster.

I will differ a bit from the other answers and assume here that you are only referring to the mosquitoes whose females actually bite humans (or maybe only the Anopheles species that carries malaria. If you were to only erradicate this species (or maybe only the biting species) I think there is a good possibility that some other species might expand their ecological niche and take over their ecological role without the catastrophic cascades of extinctions and ecological collapse that the other answers foresee. (Note that it is by no means certain that this niche expansion will occur though). However, my bigger question will be how you will go about eradicating only mosquitoes or only specific species of mosquitoes without eradicating a host of other species as well? I do not think it is likely or maybe even possible to eradicate only biting mosquitoes without killing a large number of other beneficial species as well. The only way I can think of, is if you somehow poisoned the blood of all people in mosquito areas (and probably the blood of all other potential animal hosts, as well)... I don't think this is really achievable.

It would primarily effect the birds, frogs, and fish that eat mosquitoes and the mosquito larvae. That could disrupt the food chain of the animals that eat birds, fish and frogs, which could effect the population of the higher animals. The idea that humans have that you can eradicate a long standing species without harm is a lesson that most humans have not learned. Almost everything that lives on this planet consumes food that is made by or is another species. If you break the chain, you cause problems such as wiping out other species that depend on the initial one killed off, or you let loose a harmful species that was controlled by the existence of the species that was wiped out. Example, if you got rid of the cats, the mouse and rat populations would expand because the cats are natural hunters of the rats and mice.

There would disadvantages as well as benefits if this was to happen. Certain diseases, like Malaria and the Zika virus would just about vanish, and, of course, we would not have any swollen, itchy lumps on us. These lumps are actually because of the numbing juice the mosquito injects. This decreases the victim's chances of noticing it and swatting it. After the mosquito is satisfied, it flies away and the juice 'inflates' the tissue, and irritates it. Female mosquitoes are the only ones that suck blood. Males consume nectar. Females do too, but that is only for food. The blood is to give her nutrients to grow eggs. Because of this, they play a role in pollination. They are the main diet of bats and some birds, frogs, and spiders. Fun fact: They do not have the best vision, but are attracted to mammals by C0₂ (Carbon Dioxide) gas during an animal's exhalation.

A. It is impossible to know for sure, because so many varieties of mosquitoes fill so many environmental niches, feeding on and being fed on by such a variety of other creatures, and because many of these interactions have not been studied. But it is only natural that people, pestered by itchy bites and bearing the brunt of mosquito-borne diseases, would hope the answer is no. Many birds, bats, amphibians, fish, spiders and other insects feed on mosquitoes, but many mosquito-control specialists say they usually do not eat enough mosquitoes to control them, let alone to make the loss of mosquitoes crucial to whether the predators survive. In-depth studies have found that mosquitoes form at most 3 percent of the voracious purple martin’s diet, according to the American Mosquito Control Association. A survey of scientists on mosquito eradication, published in 2010 by the journal Nature, concluded by quoting the head of the association, who said that eradication would be a “hiccup” for the environments where mosquitoes are active and that “something better or worse would take over.”—C. CLAIBORNE RAY

1.Mosquito repelant industry will crash and many would be jobless2.No malaria - no long leaves from job/school3.Unpredictable imbalance in the food chain. The whole food web may crash4.exponential population explosion as no one will get infected from malaria, dengue, etc.5.huge pressure on all earthly resources6.wars all over the world for natural resources7.new cia mission in south east asia, Africa and Brazil to have a war like situation in these places so that usa could get hold of all forest resources (and it would be easy as there would be no mosquitoes in the forests)8.apocalypse due to nuclear warThere you see how important mosquitoes are!save them :P

This is a very interesting question. Most people would love to be rid of all mosquitoes on the planet because they are such a menace. They are noisy, they don’t let you sleep, they behave like drunk houseflies and they spread some very deadly diseases among human beings. But would nature have let mosquitoes live without any reason? Absolutely not. There are 3,500 named species of mosquito, of which only a couple of hundred bite or bother humans. They live on almost every continent and habitat, and serve important functions in numerous ecosystems. I have written about this exact question on my blog: Mosquitoes: A necessary evil. Do check it out. I’m sure this will answer your question. Some scientists do agree that extermination of just the disease causing mosquitoes would not cause major ecological imbalance. Mosquitoes occupy a particular niche in the ecosystem that can easily be filled by other insects. There will be some damage, but it expected to be short term. I hope this helps. Cheers!

There will be an ecological imbalance. Mosquitoes are not only human/social pest, but also food for some larger organisms viz., frogs, lizards. Every living organism though useful or harmful is a part of nature.They act as vectors (spreading vehicle) for various diseases in human. Mechanism to control them have already been developed. If all the mosquitoes are wiped off, some other insect may develop its superiority to replace them. They might spread a new disease, which firstly becomes a difficult task to control it. Developing new mechanisms to control will be tedious task and meanwhile there will be huge human loss.

Every insect every creature has a purpose in this world . Some we can't even fathom . Sample this…… If we were to annhilate all the mosquitoes of the word a full food chain and a circle of life would disappear. Mosquitoes are food for the frogs and small birds ….frogs are eaten by the snakes who are in turn eaten by the Birds of prey like Hawks ,Eagles, owls etc . Can you realise how many species would get affected if such a thing would happen? Every creature Every being has a purpose on this planet and an equal right to live . What seems a pest to us is food for another . So learn to accept all . Peace

In nature every creature big or small plays a significant role in the niche of the ecosystem they occupy, take mosquitoes for instance; the larvae feed on algae in the water body they find themselves and are quite effective in cleaning the water. The goal in pest management is not necessarily eradication but population control. Mosquitoes may serve a vital purpose we don't fully understand yet like ensuring there's competition and pressure on potential pest species. Truth is, most pest species were not that originally but the alterations of their ecosystems and subsequent removal of predators and competition (whether intentionally or not) led to the surge in their population and adaptation to the altered environment and behold a pest is born. So eradicating mosquitoes might just unleash a greater enemy as the saying goes “ the devil you know is better than the angel you don't know”.

All mosquitoes disappearing might leave insectivorous birds like swallows short of food, with further knock-on effects. Ditto small fish that eat their larvae and the larger fish that eat the smaller fish. Just the anopheles mosquito (that spreads malaria) probably wouldn't be missed, except by malaria parasites which would hopefully go extinct. Other mosquitoes would doubtless fill the small ecological niche vacated.

When a vector (an insect that carries disease and transmits it by biting) suddenly disappears that does not mean that the disease itself disappears so malaria, dengue fever, and other mosquito borne illnesses would NOT disappear though they would, for a period, become more rare. There are no insect predators that feed exclusively on mosquitos except in very small locales so those species would be immediately impacted, too, but needing a replacement food source would lead to an evolutionary change IF the mosquito eaters could adapt BEFORE their extinction. I do know that if mosquitoes disappeared suddenly the flies, gnats, small sweat bees (the Halictidae family), horse flies and other annoying insects would still make summer evenings a miserable time, maybe without all the itching though, without some chemical intervention on the part of humans. Most humans would not notice the extinction of the species until long after it happened.

Several other species which rely on the mosquito for food or procreation would also vanish. The human population would increase even faster due to fewer deaths from mosquito transmittable diseases, putting additional pressure on unrelated species. Total ecosystem collapse due to famine, climate change and pollution might occur up to 100 years earlier. Let's ask another question, what would happen if a mosquito bite left you sterile? The human population declines rapidly. In a generation population is halved. Climate change is practically halted. Ecosystem collapse is averted. Nobody dies but a liveable world exists for the children that are born and keep out of the forest.

It isn’t likely to happen, but if it was possible and they were all exterminated, many fish and animals that feed extensively on the mosquitoes would die. For example, although the little brown bat eats a number of different flying insects, in many areas, its diet consists mostly of mosquitoes. That is partly because of the number of mosquitoes, but the point is that if mosquitoes were wiped out, the food supply would be enormously restricted. Many other insects also feed on mosquitoes, especially in larval form.

Like all other oraganisms mosquito is also a part of the Food chain. Since it bite human beings it is hated by many people, But the fact is only a tiny number of mosquito species bite people, and very few transmit disease. Mosquito is a favorite food for many predators, It is also a pollinator and apart from this there is a insect called Botfly depends on mosquitoes to carry its larvae to hosts. The botfly lays eggs on the mosquito, which hatch and jump off when the mosquito lands on a mammal. The botfly larvae then burrow into the mammal and develop there. Botfly (Cephenemyia stimulator)  So tell me now…What happens if mosquitoes are not there on the earth? Thank you

User-11401271720827733261 gave a good answer — we can hypothesize what might happen, but it's hard to test. Malaria and other mosquito borne diseases would decrease in frequency, if not disappear entirely. I suspect food webs would be affected, especially in hot and humid environments where mosquito populations are dense. The map below suggests mosquito population sizes are small in Canada and some other places. Here in the southern U.S., mosquitoes are abundant (that's an understatement). I think ecosystems here would be noticeably changed. If another insect evolved to take advantage of the mosquitoe’s ecological niche, I think they'd look and behave a LOT like mosquitoes. They're very specialized. I think we will go extinct before they do.  Map source: CDC: Global Distribution of Potentially Important Malaria Vectors, 2012.

Not a lot in the way of anything dangerous ..a good thing will be it will prevent the spread of malaria. .some might say ebola or even HIV OR AIDS but that is debatable by some people guess only a a scientist in that field could only say it is true ..I'm only a painter and Decorator and industrial Sprayer. .. NOT A SCIENTIST..ohh yeah also all the animals that eat them will die which could eventually means humans aswell. …

Mosquitoes are quite important species that serve as primary and secondary food sources for many other insects and small fish. If mosquitoes vanish, then the number of insects and fish that feed on them would decline as well. However, not all scientists share my sentiment. For example, an article published in Nature featured a couple of renowned researchers claiming the world would be a better place without mosquitoes, and that the vacant niche (previously occupied by the insects) would be easily taken by other species.

The worst thing that will happen in this scenario is that there will be many more people. That would be awful. There are quite enough people on the planet already. An article in Nature magazine stated that the loss of the species wouldn’t impact the environment too badly and that predators would switch to other food sources. I’d be able to sleep in the summer much better. All sorts of diseases wouldn’t be transmitted as easily. “Off” would go out of business. We’d need to come up with another way to kill off 200 million people per year.

Insectivores would begin to starve.Some mammals (such as humans) would become EXTREMELY overpopulated due to the lack of bacterial/viral population controlStagnant pools of water would become highly polluted, decimating the habitat of fairy shrimp and other vernal pool species.Certain plants would die due to the extinction of an important pollinator.

Then the world would be very different. In some ways better, in others worse. The better thing, no more annoying mosquitoes!!! :D the worse thing, the extinction of mosquitoes would cause other species to go extinct or at least their populations to drop. Mosquitoes are food to some other species. Such as dragonflies. What’s gonna happen to them if so much of their food is gone? I’m sure they eat other things too, but without mosquitoes their population will drop.

I’d be forever thankful. In truth Mosquitoes have a huge impact in the food chain. They are food to many birds and other insects as well many kinds of fish eat up the mosquito larvae. If they just disappeared, there would be a present vacuum and many species of animals may suffer starvation until another animal fills in the gap. In the long run, we really aren’t to certain what would specifically happen, but there is one positive, but just for humans: no more bites in the summer!

I remember being on a school field trip and hearing about how they actually tried once in my home state. They used a dispersed chemical agent dropped in ponds and lakes that kept the larvae from hatching or something. Apparently they did some real damage to several species of birds and fish, and almost caused a type of herron to go extinct. Seems that Mosquitos actually form a pretty vital part of the food chain in a lot of areas.

For that to happen, something cataclysmic happened that probably stopped all nerve kinetics. If it killed them, then it also killed most other insects that size. That means predators like bats are going to starve in many cases as are the insectavoirs that eat similar species. The entire eco system will ripple, but malaria is contained.

Good question. Mosquitoes have killed about 500 million people in past 100 years (the last official figure I saw was in 1990 and then it was 350 million since the start of the 20th century). So, mosquitoes have killed more people than all the wars combined, over and over. And they are still killing people every day. Not just locals, but tourists that go to mosquito infested places which are declared ‘malarial’ because more than 5% of the population carry the parasite. My son Elon contracted malaria after a four day visit to a ‘luxury’ game lodge in South Africa. He was lucky to survive and that only because of intense medical attention directed hour by hour between SA and the US, with my brother, a tropical diseases specialist, as the go-between.

There are about 3,500 species of mosquitos. Less than 6 percent bite humans and the rest couldn't bite humans even if they tried to. The rest feed on plants and pollinate flowers. Mosquitoes are an important food source for other animals, including birds, bats, frogs, arthropods, amphibians, and fish. So obviously, it would cause very serious ecological damage and millions of people would die, and ecosystems would collapse. Just killing Eurasian tree sparrows in China led to the Chinese Great famine which killed 15 to 40 million people, so 3,500 species and an entire family of important insects going globally extinct would be exponentially worse.

I belive not. Mosquitoes are a food source for some creatues, but i think they could easily replaced by moths, flys, and other flying insects. This would be a really bad bit of data suggesting things have really gotten out of hand. I have no space ship, political or military power. A majority of my companions do think this would amount to much so proceeding with the bucket list is all that comes to mind.

the world rejoices as malaria and several other diseases are quickly eradicated, soon a new invasive species will come along and fill it’s boots so that the birds and other animals that prayed on them can eat, hopefully they’re less annoying and dangerous than mosquitoes though

A lot of other insect species (such as dragonflies) and amphibians (such as frogs) will either see significant reductions in their overall population or may disappear entirely. And then animals that rely on the frogs and dragonflies as food sources will suffer, as well. It’ll keep going like this depending on how much the next animal requires the previous one as a food source.

On the one hand, no more mosquito bites and mosquito-spread infections, so yay. On the other, you’re going to see a pretty significant negative impact on bats, birds and other useful things which feed on them.
Companies which sell mosquito repellent would go bankrupt!

Malaria would disappear for one. People would not get bitten by so many insects. Some plants would not get pollinated (a small side effect), and insignificant in the grand scheme, and a niche would become available that other insects could fill.
A lot of small fish would go hungry.

There would be an ecological impact. Male mosquitoes, for instance, eat nectar, making some species major pollinators of plants such as some crops and flowers—even orchids. Similarly, mosquitoes of all ages and sexes serve as a food source for all kinds of creatures, such as fish, turtles, dragonflies, migratory songbirds, and bats.

Definitely would for the mosquito ecosystem. Many fish, frogs, birds, spiders and insects that rely on mosquito larvae and mosquitoes themselves… but they'll just have to adapt and improvise their daily nutritional intake with anything higher than the nutritional value of a McDonald's Happy Meal.
Dragonflies will have a problem. So too some fishes which eat mosquitoes. In general there will be a major ecological imbalance.

Actually mosquitoes play a big and important role in our world. That’s why we need to quit thinking we know it all when it comes to the environment and living systems. Check out this insightful answer: Anand Nyamdavaa's answer to What is the purpose of mosquitoes and flies on earth?
